subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 19th July 2019: Fed downplays chance of 50bps cut; two UK tankers seized by Iran
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities down, Treasuries, dollar up, crude.
  • REAR VIEW: IRGC seizes two UK ships; Fed sources push back on 50bps cut expectations; ECB may restart bond purchases as early as November; Italian election risk returns
  • COMING UP: MONDAY: Data; US National Activity Index; Speakers; BoJ’s Kuroda, RBA’s Kent, TUESDAY: Data; US Existing Home Sales, US API Crude Stocks, NZ Trade Balance, Speakers; BoE’s Haldane, Auctions; UK 2029 Gilt, US 2yr Note, Earnings; Lockheed Martin, Coca-Cola, Visa, United Technologies, Santander, ASM, UBS, WEDNESDAY: Data; Australian PMIs, EZ and US Flash PMIs, Weekly DoEs, Auctions; US 5yr Note, Earnings; Boeing, Facebook, Ford, Caterpillar, Tesla, LVMH, Deutsche Bank, Iberdrola, Daimler, Peugeot, GSK, THURSDAY: Events; CBRT and ECB Rate Decision, Data; SK GDP, German Ifo, US Durable Goods, Canadian Average Earnings, Speakers; RBA’s Lowe, ECB’ Draghi, Earnings; Amazon, Alphabet, 3M, Raytheon, Intel Corp, Nokia, Kering, BASF, Volkswagen, Ab InBev, Roche, ABB, FRIDAY: Data; Tokyo CPI, US Q2 GDP, Earnings; McDonald’s, Colgate-Palmolive, Twitter, Renault, EDF, ENI, Nestle.

 

* MARKET WRAP: Major US equity indices moved lower throughout the US session, whilst the dollar pared Thursday’s losses, as Fed sources on Friday pushed back against expectations of a 50bps cut in July and geopolitical risk rose after 2 UK tankers were seized by Iran. The heightened security risk in the Strait of Hormuz saw crude markets bid higher later in the session, bucking the trend of consistent daily losses this week, whilst gold found some support following its downward trajectory on the day. Treasury markets were relatively subdued, but the ramp up of political tension in the Italian government saw Italian BTPs sell off and weighed on the euro, also playing into the stronger dollar.

* FED: Fed’s Williams (voter) comments from last night were played down by a NY Fed spokesman overnight stating the speech was academical and not in relation to the July meeting, helping to reduce pricing for a 50bps cut at the July meeting. President Trump also reiterated his case for low rates, agreeing with Williams’ comments that the Fed raised too fast and too early, and also urged the fed to ‘correct’ higher interest rates as he again slams current rates saying they are much higher than others who are no match for the US economically.  Fed’s arch dove Bullard (voter) who previously stated 50bp cut in July seems excessive, said he would listen to arguments for a larger rate cut, but still thought that 25bps was appropriate, and that the situation does not call for a larger cut. Later in the session, the WSJ reported that Fed sources stated that officials could signal potential for additional stimulus beyond July, and they signal a 25bp cut is likely at the July meeting as an insurance measure. They highlighted that the officials are not prepared for bolder action by making a 50bp cut as recent economic developments have not signalled an imminent downturn, which pushed the market pricing for a 50bp cut even lower to lows of 17% before paring back to 25%.

* IRAN: Iran Revolutionary Guard seized two UK shipping vessels in the space of a few hours, the first named Steno Impero and the second Mesdar, which both were seized in the latter part of the trading session, causing a ramp up of tensions in the Persian Gulf and the convening of the UK government for an emergency meeting; this came after Gibraltar announced it would be holding Iran’s Grace 1 tanker for an additional 30 days. Earlier in the session, finger pointing between Washington and Tehran ensued; Iran denied that the US had shot down one of its drones on Thursday, and claimed that the US may have even blown up one of its own drones; Iran state TV also showed evidence which claimed to prove that the US’ claims were false. Perhaps unsurprisingly, President Trump rejected the Iran denial, as did a separate US administration who added that if Iran continues to fly drones too close to US ships, the US will continue to shoot them down. The same official, commenting on Iran Foreign Minister Zarif’s “substantial” nuclear offer for the removal of US sanctions, said the US had dismissed the offer due to Washington not seeing any evidence Zarif has any decision-making power. Although the back-and-forth comments continued, US Secretary of State Pompeo did say that the Trump is still prepared to conduct talks with Iran without preconditions; adding that they need the Iranians to come to the table for negotiations. On which note; the Iranian Foreign Minister Zarif reportedly met with Senator Rand Paul on Thursday to discuss the potential prospects for talks between Iran and US.

* ITALY: Political Tensions in Italy have tightened with an Italian League Official saying it is hard to continue governing with the 5 Star Movement. Following this, Italy’s Deputy PM Salvini confirmed earlier reports that he will meet with coalition partner Di Maio, however an official later stated no meetings have yet been scheduled. Salvini added the problem is not Deputy PM Di Maio, rather opposition coming from 5 Star lawmakers. Despite the political tensions, Di Maio ruled out a government crisis this morning, and President Mattarella said he has not received any indication that League leader Salvini wants to collapse the government. Also, Mattarella has always made it clear he wants a government in place over October to approve the 2020 budget and that any potential early election should be held either in early October, or in the first few months of 2020, to ensure the budget is approved. Deputy PM Conte also announced significant steps have been made on the autonomy bill, which is what the league wanted, and he hopes this will help ease political tensions in the nation.

* TRADE: As expected, US treasury Secretary Mnuchin and USTR Lighthizer stated they discussed trade over the phone with Chinese officials, striking a positive tone on the US-China front. This was later followed by China’s Global Times Editor (Xu Xijin) tweeting that the Chinese side sees a face-to-face meeting with the US as not far away, and expects "actions" may happen soon, which he believes would be a sign of goodwill from both sides. US President Trump said Mnuchin’s call with the Chinese had been very good.

* US UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN INDEX: The July preliminary UoM index headline figure came in at 98.4 (exp. 98.5), rising slightly from 98.2 in June, whilst expectations came in slightly stronger at 90.1 (exp. 89.8) and current conditions slightly soft at 111.1 (exp. 112). Analysts at Oxford Economics comment, “Excluding a brief surge in May, the headline index has been remarkably stable between 97.2 and 98.4 over the past five months.” The closely watched inflation gauges had 1-year falling 0.1ppt from June to 2.6%, and the 5-year rose 0.3ppt from June to 2.6%. Capital Economics comments that the pickup in the longer-term inflation expectations is a positive given the all-time low in the prior, but is unlikely to address concerns of several Fed officials of persistent undershooting of inflation.

* SOUTH KOREA/JAPAN: A Japanese Trade Ministry official said it will be difficult to discuss trade measures and policy with South Korea if the country does not rebuild trust, adding that the global supply chain will not be at risk from the South Korean export issue. However, US President Trump offered to help ease tensions between the two as they are two of its largest allies in Asia.

* PBOC: The central bank stated they will implement appropriate counter cyclical adjustments and they are to keep prudent monetary policy where it is not too loose nor too tight. They also mentioned they are to keep measures to fend off financial risks in key areas, and are to keep M2 and social financing growth in line with the nominal GDP growth.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (U9) SETTLED 3+ TICKS LOWER AT 127-17: The T-plex got off on the backfoot overnight and into the European session as the market pared back the dovish reaction from Fed’s Williams on Thursday. Although support was provided on the back of some disappointing German PPI data, where the Bund strength spread into wider government bonds. A mixed July (prelim.) University of Michigan survey didn’t cause a stir. Later in the US session, there was some further selling as Fed’s Bullard affirmed his preference to a 25bps rate cut at the July meeting, which was then echoed by Fed sources claiming that the general sentiment among Fed members was also for a 25bps cut. However, news of British shipping vessels being seized in the Persian Gulf saw bidding into the settlement, at which, the curve had flattened, seeing the 2s10s narrowing by approximately 3.5bps.

* WTI FUTURES (U9) SETTLED USD 0.34 HIGHER AT USD 55.76; BRENT FUTURES (U9) SETTLED USD 0.54 HIGHER AT USD 62.47/BBL: Crude prices on Friday echoed the majority of the week; modest gains in the European session before paring back in US trading; however, the Iranian seizing of a UK ship saw the pattern break with a late session rally. Analysts at PVM comment, “There is a pattern developing, which shows the diverging views on the two sides of the Atlantic.” Fundamentals were supportive in the early session; bullish bets rode the pick-up in geopolitical risk following the alleged downing of an Iranian drone on Thursday evening, a worsening in sentiment around the US open fed through into crude markets. However, the losses were later reversed, as news broke that the Iran Revolutionary Guard had seized a UK shipping vessel. Baker Hughes US rig count saw oil rigs -5 at 779, gas rigs +2 at 174, total rigs -4 at 954.

* S&P 500 -0.6% at 2977, NASDAQ-100 -0.9% at 7835, Dow Jones -0.3% at 27156, SECTORS; S&P 500 Consumer Discretionary -0.7%, S&P 500 Consumer Staples -0.7%, S&P 500 Energy 0.5%, S&P 500 Financials -0.5%, S&P 500 Health Care -1.1%, S&P 500 Industrials 0.5%, S&P 500 Information Technology -0.6%, S&P 500 Materials 0.3%, S&P 500 Telecommunication Services -1.3%, S&P 500 Utilities -1.5%.

* EARNINGS: Microsoft (MSFT) shares jumped higher after the co. reported earnings; the co. beat on top and bottom lines, but more importantly exceeded expectations in terms of its Cloud revenue. PC and Productivity and Business Processes also exceeded revenue expectations. American Express (AXP) posted stronger than expected profits, while revenue came in largely inline. The co. reaffirmed FY19 guidance, however desks noted expectations for a revision higher and as such AXP shares were pressured lower. CrowdStrike (CRWD) was an outperformer, shooting higher after the co. posted decent earnings, which included an upwards revision to 2020 guidance and impressive ARR and subscription revenue (desks noted record numbers of customers added and a low churn rate). State Street (STT) made decent gains after beating on the bottom line, with fee income (especially in Asset Management and FX) also better than expected. Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) moved higher after beating on top and bottom lines, with the co.’s da Vinci Surgical Systems seeing decent demand. Other notable stocks benefitting on the back of solid earnings include; BlackRock (BLK) missed on top and bottom lines but AUM up Y/Y; Capital One Financial (COF) big beat on bottom line; Citizens Financial Group (CFG) beat on top and bottom lines with loan loss provision, net charge-offs, Tangible book value all up; Gentex Corp. (GNTX) posted a top and bottom line beat but guided lower, Skechers (SKX) posted solid beat on top and bottom lines, SSS also higher. Chewy (CHWY) sunk after reporting a larger than expected loss.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Boeing (BA) shares moved higher after the co. revealed the extent of the 737 Max grounding’s impact on its Q2 earnings (a USD 4.9bln hit), with the sum worse than some investors had feared. Amazon (AMZN) was supported after news emerged that the co. is hiring for roles in a new team called "stealth advertising innovation", which the co. hopes can disrupt the gaming industry. AT&T (T) shares moderately outperformed the market, supported by the news that the co. is considering the sale of its Puerto Rico business, which could fetch USD 3bln. Pepsi Co (PEP) shares struggled to gain traction, with the news that the co. is to acquire all outstanding shares of South Africa’s Pioneer Foods Group for USD 1.7bln weighing. Occidental Petroleum (OXY) advanced, amidst reports of Carl Icahn stepping up his fight against the co.’s acquisition of Anadarko (APC), and is pushing to replace four directors on the board. Anheuser-Busch InBev (BUD) shares jumped higher premarket on the news that the has agreed to divest its Australian subsidiary Carlton & United Breweries to Asahi Group Holdings for USD 11.3bln. QEP Resources (QEP) sunk on reports that Elliot Management were cutting the price of its takeover bid for the co., undermining the likely hood of the deal going through; analysts note QEP are unlikely to accept the lower offer and other bidders are yet to emerge. Gannett (GCI) shares flew higher on reports the co. is to be acquired by rival GateHouse Media, although pricing details are yet to be revealed. Molson Coors Brewing Company (TAP) moved higher after the co. raised its quarterly dividend. Philip Morris International (PM) was underpinned by an upgrade at Barclays. Travelers (TRV) was under pressure after being downgraded at Buckingham.

* FX WRAP: USD: DXY unwound yesterday’s dovish Fed related losses; assisted initially after a NY Fed spokesperson walked back on Fed’s Williams earlier dovish remarks. The buck strength continued into the US session after Fed sources diminished hopes of a 50bps cut. EUR weakness added to the equation; the return of Italian political risk prompted the downside, which was later compounded by reports that the ECB would restart govt bond purchases, perhaps as early as November. More broadly, EURUSD remains trapped within its recent 1.1200-1.1280 for now; Desks note that the pair is likely to remain stuck within its 3 month range (1.1100-1.1400); with gains and losses capped by a weak Eurozone economy, dovish ECB and political risk on the one hand, and the Fed’s dovish pivot/Trump administration’s determination for a weaker dollar on the other. The CHF has also been firming, with many attributing the Italian tensions, and some desks see EURCHF 1.05 ahead, as the ECB prepares to loosen policy next week (watch out for an SNB response!). Fellow safe haven JPY, however, was weaker amid aforementioned dollar strength, taking its cue from narrowing rate differentials. AUD came off somewhat, but remains up vs the greenback for the week after stronger than expected labour data. Likewise, NZD finished the week strong, after RBNZ easing expectations cooled off this week after a better inflation print. Petrocurrencies continued to feel the weight of lower oil prices, largely failing to rise on a late session crude price reversal; NOK, RUB and CAD have all felt the pressure this week, with the Loonie also weighed down by poor retail sales data on Friday. EMFX was weaker as the dollar regained poise; albeit TRY, BRL and KRW hold on to decent gains this week. For a recap of this week’s FX action, please click here.

Fed's Bullard (Voter) reiterates call for a 25bps cut at the July meeting; says a 25bps cut would give the Fed optionality for a cut later in the year
content:
On Fed policy:

says it would be difficult for the Fed not to ease at this point

  • says the Fed has to follow through on rate cuts to ratify earlier policy signals
  • sees no reason to revisit decision on timing of balance sheet runoff
  • says he would like to see a new repo facility made available, but Fed is not at that point just yet
  • says Fed is not on a pre-set path

On Inflation/Yield curve:

  • a rate cut could lift inflation expectations; markets have already made some adjustments
  • says he would like to see an upward sloping yield curve, indicating the economic expansion is likely to continue

On risks to the outlook:

  • says worse outcomes on the US trade war & too slow inflation response would also be reasons to ease policy

On future aspirations:

  • says he would be willing to serve as the Fed chair in the future

subject: New York Fed Staff Nowcast stands at 1.4% for 2019:Q2 (prev. 1.5%) and 1.9% for 2019:Q3 (prev. 1.8%)
Weekly FX Wrap: fluctuating July FOMC policy expectations the primary driver
content:
USD

A real roller-coaster ride for the Greenback as markets continue to try and determine whether the Fed will deliver a 25 bp cut at the end of the month or be more aggressive and go 50. To this end, data and surveys have been pivotal following the bumper headline NFP that slashed ½ point chances to virtually zero, and this week’s releases have been somewhat inconclusive given strong retail sales and upbeat Philly Fed findings vs disappointing housing starts, building permits and a mixed Empire State survey. However, the major shift in perceptions came via comments from Fed’s Williams on the eve of the blackout period and his assertion that it is better to act before it’s too late and the neutral rate is 0.5%. Although his remarks were later qualified as ‘academic’ rather than guidance for the July 31 FOMC, Clarida also chimed with the pre-emptive approach given heightened uncertainties and soft inflation, with the upshot that markets are now more evenly balanced on the prospect of Funds being lowered to 2-2.25% or 1.75-2%. Note, dovish dissenter Bullard repeated his preference for the former, but added that he would listen to those advocating the latter. DXY just skirting 97.000 within a 97.448-96.648 range.

CAD/AUD/NZD

The non-US Dollars have been dovetailing their major counterpart, but the Loonie has also been keeping an eye on crude prices, global trade developments and Canadian data after the BoC underlined its contingent stance last week. However, Usd/Cad carved out its extremes for the week in the last 2 sessions when a new ytd low of 1.3016 was followed by a sharp rebound to just over 1.3100 in wake of sub-forecast retail sales. Conversely, the Aussie and Kiwi both derived momentum from data in the form of jobs (full time) and Q2 CPI respectively, but Aud/Usd faded ahead of 0.7100 and the 200 DMA (0.7090) as GS reaffirmed its call for 2 more 25 bp RBA eases pre-year end and Nzd/Usd pulled up short of 0.6800.

EUR/CHF 

The single currency displayed stoic resilience when pressured at 1.1200 vs the Greenback, but was unable to really threaten 1.1300 on rebounds amidst increasingly dovish ECB expectations ahead of next Thursday’s meeting. Moreover, another ramp up in Italian coalition Government in-fighting undermined Euro sentiment, especially vs the Franc that also outperformed the Buck on broader global trade/geopolitical grounds. Indeed, Eur/Chf is edging towards 1.1000 and Usd/Chf is hovering just above 0.9800 even though the SNB maintains its proactive monitoring and intervening mantra.

JPY 

The Yen also has a July policy gathering to consider against the backdrop of dovish BoJ pledges from Governor Kuroda and others, while Japanese inflation continues to miss target and the core rate actually slowed to a 2 year low. However, Usd/Jpy remains more in lock-step with general swings in risk appetite/aversion alongside US Treasury/JGB yield differentials and is ending the week closer to the 107.22 low than 108.37 high as relations between Japan and South Korea, the US and China/Iran remain strained (albeit Washington and Beijing have at least resumed trade talks by phone).

GBP

The Pound slid to a new 2019 trough vs the Buck as Cable crashed through 1.2400, but significantly better than expected UK retail sales and average earnings helped Sterling recoup some lost ground along with vague talk about the EU being open to looking at Irish backstop alternatives plus Parliament approval of the Burt-Benn amendment that makes it harder (albeit not impossible) for the next PM (BoJo still firm favourite over Hunt) to engineer no Brexit deal by sending MPs away from the HoC in the run up to October 31. Cable back up over 1.2500 and Eur/Gbp near 0.9857 lows vs 0.9052 at one stage.

EM 

A busy week for regional currencies with 3 Central Bank rate cuts (SARB, BI and BoK), some key data, twists and turns on the domestic political front and diplomatic factors all in the mix. However, the Rand and Lira look set to post net gains vs the Dollar on a hawkish shift after the 25 bp ease and more aid for Eskom, while US President Trump is still holding off on Turkish sanctions despite the arrival of Russian S-400 missiles (or part-delivery of the system) and ending F-35 engagement. Usd/Zar circa 13.9100 vs 14.0380-13.8165 boundaries and Usd/Try around 5.6470 from 5.7325 and 5.6155 at the extremes.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 19th July 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European equities are mostly lower [Eurostoxx 50 -0.2%] as Fed fuelled momentum wanes
  • New York Fed stated that the comments made by Fed's Williams were academic, based on research and not about potential policy actions at the upcoming FOMC meeting
  • Italy underperforms on domestic political angst, FTSE MIB and BTPs lower
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, Canadian Retail Sales, University of Michigan Sentiment (Prelim), Baker Hughes Rig Count, Fed’s Bullard and Rosengren, BoJ Governor Kuroda
  • Earnings: American Express, Schlumberger, State Street

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were positive across the board as the region took its cue from the late gains in US following dovish comments from Fed's Williams who suggested it is better to take preventative measures on rates and that the long-run neutral rate for US interest rates is 0.5%, although the New York Fed later clarified the rhetoric was academic and not about potential policy action this month. Nonetheless, ASX 200 (+0.8%) was led higher by strength in the mining sector especially gold-related stocks after the precious metal surged to a fresh 6-year high on the Fed comments and with NAB front running the gains for financials after it appointed RBS head McEwan as its next CEO. Nikkei 225 (+2.0%) outperformed as exporters cheered currency outflows, while Hang Seng (+1.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.8%) conformed to optimism after US-China trade negotiators resumed discussions via telephone and with the PBoC’s liquidity efforts resulting to a net weekly liquidity injection of CNY 460bln. Finally, 10yr JGBs gained as they tracked the upside in T-notes amid the dovish Fed bets, but with upside limited by the lack of safe-haven demand and slightly softer demand in the enhanced-liquidity auction for 2yr-20yr JGBs.

PBoC injected CNY 100bln via 7-day reverse repos; injects net CNY 460bln for the week vs. Prev. CNY 220bln drain. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8635 (Prev. 6.8761)

USTR Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Mnuchin discussed trade over the phone with Chinese officials as expected. (Newswires)

Japanese National CPI (Jun) Y/Y 0.7% vs. Exp. 0.7% (Prev. 0.7%). (Newswires) Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food (Jun) Y/Y 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. 0.8%) Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food & Energy (Jun) Y/Y 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.5%)

US

New York Fed stated that the comments made by Fed's Williams were academic, based on research and was not about potential policy actions at the upcoming FOMC meeting. (Newswires) REMINDER: Fed's Williams (Voter, Hawkish) said it is better to take preventative measures on rates than to wait for a disaster to unfold and that the long-run neutral rate for US interest rates is 0.5%.

Fed's Bullard (dove, voter) would listen to arguments for a larger rate cut, but thinks 25bps is appropriate; doesn't think the situation calls for a larger cut, WSJ reports. (WSJ)

GEOPOLITICS

Foreign Minister Zarif later stated that Iran has no information regarding losing a drone. (Newswires/WSJ/Twitter) 

Iran Foreign Minister Zarif reportedly met with UN Secretary General Guterres in New York and discussed seizure of Iranian tanker by the British Navy, while there were separate reports that Zarif warned about mounting tensions and that we cannot “discount” possibility of war but also stated nobody wants a war. (Newswires/The National Interest)

UK/EU

Italian League Official said its is hard to continue governing with the 5 Star Movement. Italian Deputy PM Salvini confirmed he will be meeting coalition partner Di Maio; adds the problem is not Deputy PM Di Maio, but other opposition coming from many 5 Star lawmakers. (Newswires)

UK Justice Secretary Gauke is set to step down soon after PM May completes last PM Questions on Wednesday, while Chancellor Hammond and International Development Secretary Stewart are also mulling quitting before Johnson becomes next PM. (Times)

EQUITIES

European equities have given up earlier gains and now trade mostly lower [Eurostoxx 50 -0.2%] as the initial upside momentum seen in Asia and on Wall St. following the dovish comments from Fed voter Williams somewhat waned. The New York Fed downplayed the comments as being more academic than potential near-term policy action. It’s also worth noting that the initial support for equities also came amid comments from Fed’s Vice Chair Clarida who acknowledged the increased global uncertainties and soft US inflation, which somewhat revived market pricing for a 50bps manoeuvre at the July 31st meeting. Italy’s FTSE MIB (-1.2%) lags amid reports of a possible coalition crisis as ties between the League and 5SM sour, whilst speculation about the possibility of early Italian elections in Autumn did the rounds in Italian press on Friday. Sectors are mostly higher with some underperformance in defensive sector, albeit the Consumer Staples is buoyed by AB InBev (+4.3%) as shares surged amid the sale of its of its Australian unit to Japan’s Asahi for USD 11.3bln in a bid to nurse part of its debt. Furthermore, reports stated that the Co. is also mulling the sale of its South Korean and Central American units. On the flip side, shares in Publicis (-8.4%) declined due to a cut in its FY 19 organic growth guidance, as such WPP (-3.0%) fell in sympathy.

FX

DXY - The Buck continues to see-saw through US data points, survey findings and the final pre-FOMC commentary from Fed officials ahead of the black-out period that begins at COB today. On that note, Williams and Clarida provided ‘guidance’ and despite denials or clarification of the former rate expectations have shifted again, with the probability of a 25 bp or 50 bp ease now much closer to even vs circa 75%/25% after Thursday’s upbeat Philly Fed survey. In response, the Greenback weakened vs all major rivals and the index hit a 96.750 low before tentatively regaining 97.000 status and holding above support, as Usd/G10 pairs pare back or rebound from late yesterday/overnight extremes. Note, remarks from renowned dove Bullard are not really impacting as he repeats his preference for smaller policy adjustment, though would countenance arguments in favour of ½ point.

JPY - Having benefited most from the aforementioned Dollar retreat, and with added safe-haven premium gleaned via another US-Iran dispute (former claims that a drone was downed and latter denies any damage), the Yen is now ‘underperforming’. However, Usd/Jpy remains well below the 108.00 axis that has been constricting trade and with decent option expiries now capping the pair along with technical resistance (1.1 bn between 107.90-108.05, 55 DMA at 107.87 and daily chart level at 107.88).

EUR - The single currency is still flanked between 1.1200 and 1.1300 parameters with ECB policy stimulus weighing against Fed easing and only days separating the respective July policy meetings. Note also, Italian coalition Government conflicts are coming to a head and expiry interest may also be dragging Eur/Usd down given 1.2 bn rolling off from 1.1240-25 and 1.55 bn at 1.1210-00.

AUD/CHF/NZD/GBP/CAD - The Aussie ran up against some key chart hurdles ahead of 0.7100, like the 200 DMA (0.7090) after extending its rebound from just under 0.7000 with some encouragement from the US and China conducting trade dialogue over the phone. However, Aud/Usd is holding above 0.7050 where export bids are touted and if those are filled there are said to be more underlying buy orders between 0.7040-30 linked to 900 mn expiries residing from 0.7035 to 0.7025. Elsewhere, the Franc has faded into 0.9800 and Kiwi not far from 0.6800, while the Pound topped out around 1.2550 and the Loonie continues to pull-up on approaches to 1.3000, with Canadian retail sales data looming.

EM - Amidst widespread declines vs the Usd, Zar losses or rather retracement from post-SARB highs has been compounded by more SA political issues as current President Ramaphosa joins a former counterpart in the corruption dock. Rand currently closer to the base of 13.9410-8165 parameters.

FIXED INCOME

Gilts had another close look at the 131.50 level that broadly aligns with yesterday’s intraday best (131.52) and chart resistance in the form of last Thursday’s Liffe session high (131.51), but topped out at 131.49 before fading alongside Bunds and with US Treasuries succumbing to a bit more retracement from their post-Fed Williams and Clarida peaks. UK bonds also erred on the side of caution into the last of this week’s domestic data releases as the Government’s finances came under scrutiny just a day after a rather bleak OBR report on the outlook if Britain left the EU without a deal. In the event PSNB balances were worse than forecast and only partly compensated by revisions to the previous month.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures are consolidating following the recent decline which was exacerbated by refineries in the Gulf of Mexico restarting operations after the passing of storm Barry, with reports stating that only 19% of production is currently offline vs. 73% on Sunday. Upside in the complex is also supported by the rising geopolitical tensions after US President Trump stated that the US took defensive actions and downed an Iranian drone, a statement which was denied by Iranian officials. Furthermore, IRGC said that Iran will release images to disprove US’ claim. WTI and Brent futures currently reside just above 56/bbl and 63/bbl and with little by way of notable DMAs given the recent slump in prices. Elsewhere, precious metal prices have drifted lower after rallying on the dovish comments from Fed voters Williams and Clarida coupled with the aforementioned geopolitical developments, in which gold hit a fresh 6yr high and briefly breached 1450/oz to the upside. Meanwhile, copper prices are also supported by the overall risk appetite. Finally, iron ore prices were mildly pressured as Iron ore exports from Australia’s port Hedland increased 6% M/M to a record high as miners increased shipments to meet targets.

IEA Director Birol said might revise 2019 global oil demand growth forecast to 1.1mln bpd from 1.3mln bpd, while he added they don’t expect a huge increase in oil prices as markets are awash with oil and demand is slowing. (Newswires)

BAML says Brent should continue to trade in the range of USD 60-67/bbl in H2 2019 due to "absence of binary risks" (Iran and trade wars)

EQUITIES

European equities have given up earlier gains and now trade mixed [Eurostoxx 50 Unch] as the initial upside momentum seen in Asia and on Wall St. following the dovish comments from Fed voter Williams somewhat waned. The New York Fed downplayed the comments as being more academic than potential near-term policy action. It’s also worth noting that the initial support for equities also came amid comments from Fed’s Vice Chair Clarida who acknowledged the increased global uncertainties and soft US inflation, which somewhat revived market pricing for a 50bps manoeuvre at the July 31st meeting. Italy’s FTSE MIB (-1.2%) lags amid rumours of a possible coalition crisis as ties between the League and 5SM sour, whilst speculation about the possibility of early Italian elections in Autumn did the rounds in Italian press on Friday. Sectors are mostly higher with some underperformance in defensive sector, albeit the Consumer Staples is buoyed by AB InBev (+4.3%) as shares surged amid the sale of its of its Australian unit to Japan’s Asahi for USD 11.3bln in a bid to nurse part of its debt. Furthermore, reports stated that the Co. is also mulling the sale of its South Korean and Central American units. On the flip side, shares in Publicis (-8.4%) declined due to a cut in its FY 19 organic growth guidance, as such WPP (-3.0%) fell in sympathy.

FX

DXY - The Buck continues to see-saw through US data points, survey findings and the final pre-FOMC commentary from Fed officials ahead of the black-out period that begins at COB today. On that note, Williams and Clarida provided ‘guidance’ and despite denials or clarification of the former rate expectations have shifted again, with the probability of a 25 bp or 50 bp ease now much closer to even vs circa 75%/25% after Thursday’s upbeat Philly Fed survey. In response, the Greenback weakened vs all major rivals and the index hit a 96.750 low before tentatively regaining 97.000 status and holding above support, as Usd/G10 pairs pare back or rebound from late yesterday/overnight extremes. Note, remarks from renowned dove Bullard are not really impacting as he repeats his preference for smaller policy adjustment, though would countenance arguments in favour of ½ point.

JPY - Having benefited most from the aforementioned Dollar retreat, and with added safe-haven premium gleaned via another US-Iran dispute (former claims that a drone was downed and latter denies any damage), the Yen is now ‘underperforming’. However, Usd/Jpy remains well below the 108.00 axis that has been constricting trade and with decent option expiries now capping the pair along with technical resistance (1.1 bn between 107.90-108.05, 55 DMA at 107.87 and daily chart level at 107.88).

subject: Bunds: some signs of fatigue approaching the end of a constructive week
content: Eurozone bond futures remain firm on the back of more dovish Central Bank momentum and an element of safe-haven demand given the fractious global trade and geopolitical backdrop, but bullish momentum appears to have waned somewhat after an impressive rebound so far this week. Indeed, Bunds have drifted back down from Eurex highs that fell a few ticks short of Thursday late peak (173.57 vs 173.63), and 173.70 technical resistance is still proving elusive ahead of 174.00 and the 174.05 July 4th contract pinnacle, while even higher flying Italian BTPs have retreated a bit further from their new 140.24 apex set yesterday. Pre-weekend consolidation could be keep buyers at bay along with positioning and hedging for the upcoming ECB meeting, BoJ and FOMC.

ASIA

Asian equity markets were positive across the board as the region took its cue from the late gains in US following dovish comments from Fed's Williams who suggested it is better to take preventative measures on rates and that the long-run neutral rate for US interest rates is 0.5%, although the New York Fed later clarified the rhetoric was academic and not about potential policy action this month. content:

  • 19th July 2019 

·        Asian equity markets were positive across the board as the region took its cue from the late gains in US following dovish comments from Fed's Williams

·        However, these were later clarified as academic comments and not about potential policy action this month

·        The US shot down an Iranian drone which was said to have approached to within a threatening distance of the USS Boxer

·        Looking ahead, highlights include UK PSNB, Canadian Retail Sales, University of Michigan Sentiment (Prelim), Baker Hughes Rig Count, Fed’s Bullard and Rosengren, BoJ Governor Kuroda

·        Earnings: American Express, Schlumberger, BlackRock, State Street

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were positive across the board as the region took its cue from the late gains in US following dovish comments from Fed's Williams who suggested it is better to take preventative measures on rates and that the long-run neutral rate for US interest rates is 0.5%, although the New York Fed later clarified the rhetoric was academic and not about potential policy action this month. Nonetheless, ASX 200 (+0.8%) was led higher by strength in the mining sector especially gold-related stocks after the precious metal surged to a fresh 6-year high on the Fed comments and with NAB front running the gains for financials after it appointed RBS head McEwan as its next CEO. Nikkei 225 (+2.0%) outperformed as exporters cheered currency outflows, while Hang Seng (+1.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.0%) conformed to optimism after US-China trade negotiators resumed discussions via telephone and with the PBoC’s liquidity efforts resulting to a net weekly liquidity injection of CNY 460bln. Finally, 10yr JGBs gained as they tracked the upside in T-notes amid the dovish Fed bets, but with upside limited by the lack of safe-haven demand and slightly softer demand in the enhanced-liquidity auction for 2yr-20yr JGBs.

PBoC injected CNY 100bln via 7-day reverse repos; injects net CNY 460bln for the week vs. Prev. CNY 220bln drain. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8635 (Prev. 6.8761)

USTR Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Mnuchin discussed trade over the phone with Chinese officials as expected. (Newswires)

Japanese National CPI (Jun) Y/Y 0.7% vs. Exp. 0.7% (Prev. 0.7%). (Newswires) Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food (Jun) Y/Y 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. 0.8%) Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food & Energy (Jun) Y/Y 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.5%)

UK/EU

UK Justice Secretary Gauke is set to step down soon after PM May completes last PM Questions on Wednesday, while Chancellor Hammond and International Development Secretary Stewart are also mulling quitting before Johnson becomes next PM. (Times)

Potential candidates are said to be discouraged from entering in the contention for the BoE Governor role due to Brexit turmoil. (Newswires)

EC President Von Der Leyen stated that both EU 27 & UK have an interest in an ordered exit and therefore a good start to future relationships, while she answered there is flexibility in the European budgetary rules which can be used to stimulate growth through investment in response when asked about Italy’s deficit. (Newswires) 

FX

 

DXY weakened below 97.00 on the dovish rhetoric from Fed’s Williams which was followed by comments from Vice Chair Clarida that uncertainties have increased and inflation has been soft, while Clarida also suggested not to wait until the data turns decisively. These boosted hopes for a larger cut this month in which CME Fed Fund Futures briefly priced in a probability of over 70% for a 50bps cut vs. 34% the prior day, although this has since slipped back to around 44% after the New York Fed downplayed the comments by Williams. As such, EUR/USD slightly pulled back overnight but still holds on to most the gains in the aftermath of the dovish Fed speak, while GBP/USD remained near the prior day’s highs around 1.2550 helped by the recent strong Retail Sales data and Parliamentary voting. Elsewhere, the heightened risk appetite spurred outflows from safe-haven JPY which underpinned JPY-crosses, although USD/JPY was subdued by base currency effects, while antipodeans benefitted from the broad USD weakness, as well as gains in commodities and due to their high beta properties.

COMMODITIES

Commodities traded higher as prices gained on the back of a softer USD and heightened risk appetite, which provided WTI crude futures with some much-needed respite from this week’s declines after a brief slip to below the USD 55.00/bbl. WTI has since reclaimed the USD 56.00/bbl and is up around 1.5% for the session with prices also underpinned by geopolitical tensions after reports the US shot down an Iranian drone which was said to have approached to within a threatening distance of the USS Boxer, while Iran’s Foreign Minister also suggested that the possibility of a war cannot be discounted although added that nobody would want that to occur. Elsewhere, gold prices rallied to fresh 6-year highs above the USD 1450/oz level in the aftermath of the dovish rhetoric from Fed’s Williams but then slightly pulled back after the New York Fed pushed back against these comments, and copper outperformed as it reflected that rally across stocks.

 

IEA Director Birol said might revise 2019 global oil demand growth forecast to 1.1mln bpd from 1.3mln bpd, while he added they don’t expect a huge increase in oil prices as markets are awash with oil and demand is slowing. (Newswires)

 

US Gulf of Mexico crude oil production remains cut by approximately 19% due to storm Barry. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump said the US took defensive action against an Iranian drone and destroyed it and the Pentagon also announced the US took defensive action after the Iranian drone came within a "threatening" distance of the USS Boxer, although Iran Foreign Minister Zarif later stated that Iran has no information regarding losing a drone. (Newswires/WSJ/Twitter)

US Treasury added five people and seven entities to the sanctions lists for dealing with Iran and nuclear non-proliferation issues. The reports added that the aim is to thwart a global network of procurement for Iran's nuclear enrichment programme and that the targets of the sanctions are in Belgium, Iran, and China. (Newswires)

Pentagon official said US is not forming a military coalition against Iran and wants multinational maritime push to shine a light on Gulf to deter attacks. The official also commented the US has received signs of interest to escort ships through the Strait of Hormuz but added that multinational maritime initiative won't materialise overnight and may take months. (Newswires)

Iran’s Rouhani said in a phone call with French President Macron that Iran is determined to leave all doors open to save the nuclear deal, while there were separate reports that Iran made a 'substantial' nuclear offer in return for US lifting sanctions which would allow enhanced and permanent nuclear inspections although it was also said to likely to be a non-starter. (The Guardian)

Iran Foreign Minister Zarif reportedly met with UN Secretary General Guterres in New York and discussed seizure of Iranian tanker by the British Navy, while there were separate reports that Zarif warned about mounting tensions and that we cannot “discount” possibility of war but also stated nobody wants a war. (Newswires/The National Interest)

There were initial reports that US President Trump said he is not looking at sanctions on Turkey at the minute in relation to the purchases of the Russian air defence system, although reports later stated that President Trump said we are looking at Turkey sanctions but have not yet made a decision. (Newswires)

 

US

Treasuries reversed earlier losses in a late session rally, induced by dovish Fed speak and geopolitics. The T-plex had been gradually drifting lower throughout the Asian and European session before more selling was initiated after a strong Philly Fed index, assisted by a 13k+ block sale in the TYU9. However, the selling bottomed out going into the European equity close and losses began gradually paring back. A mixed 10-year TIPS auction didn’t buck the trend, tailing 1.8bps with a 2.45x B/C (prev. 2.99x), but had a decent takedown with indirects taking 64.3%. The tailwinds accelerated just prior to settlement as Fed’s Williams (voter) announced the need to provide accommodation, not leaving any uncertainty. At settlement the curve had bull flattened, with the 2s10s widening over 3bps. US T-note futures (U9) settled 9 ticks higher at 127-20+.

Fed's Williams (Voter, Hawkish) said it is better to take preventative measures on rates than to wait for a disaster to unfold and that the long-run neutral rate for US interest rates is 0.5%. Williams also commented that standard inflation targeting approach may anchor inflation expectations too low, while he suggested that policy makers must move more quickly to vaccinate the economy and add monetary stimulus when rates are close to zero. However, New York Fed later stated that the comments made by Fed's Williams were academic, based on research and was not about potential policy actions at the upcoming FOMC meeting. (Newswires)

Fed's Clarida (Voter, Neutral) said US economy is in a good place but uncertainties have increased and inflation has been coming in soft, while he suggested you don't want to wait until the data turns decisively. Clarida also stated that the Fed will act as appropriate to keep the economy going and that there is a limit to how far US rates can diverge from global rates. (Fox Business News)

Nonetheless, ASX 200 (+0.8%) was led higher by strength in the mining sector especially gold-related stocks after the precious metal surged to a fresh 6-year high on the Fed comments and with NAB front running the gains for financials after it appointed RBS head McEwan as its next CEO. Finally, 10yr JGBs gained as they tracked the upside in T-notes amid the dovish Fed bets, but with upside limited by the lack of safe-haven demand and slightly softer demand in the enhanced-liquidity auction for 2yr-20yr JGBs.

Nonetheless, ASX 200 (+0.7%) is led higher by strength in the mining sector especially gold-related stocks after the precious metal surged on the Fed comments and with NAB front running the gains for financials after it appointed RBS head McEwan as its next CEO. In FX markets the DXY weakened below the 97.00 level on the dovish rhetoric from Fed’s Williams which was followed by comments from Vice Chair Clarida that uncertainties have increased and inflation has been soft, while Clarida also suggested not to wait until the data turns decisively. These boosted hopes for a larger cut this month in which CME Fed Fund Futures briefly priced in a probability of over 70% for a 50bps cut vs. 34% the prior day, although this has since slipped back to around 44% after the New York Fed downplayed the comments by Williams. Elsewhere, the heightened risk appetite spurred outflows from safe-haven JPY which underpinned JPY-crosses although USD/JPY was subdued by base currency effects, while antipodeans also benefitted from the broad USD weakness, as well as gains in commodities and due to their high beta properties.
